metadata.title: Calcaneus Fracture
description: Calcaneus fracture (CF) accounts for 60% of all fractured tarsal bones, which make up 1–2%  of all fractures. Most are associated with trauma(14)
Most CFs are closed fractures with only 10% being open fractures(14)

Broad classifications of CF: 25% of CFs are extra-articular  while 75% are intra-articular,where  the subtalar joint is damaged/depressed. CFs can also be classified by whether associated fractures and soft tissue injuries of the foot are present(14) –The Sanders classification is used most commonly with CF. (See Pathogenesis below). The Sanders classification considers the presence and extent of subtalar joint fragments/depression

Treatment options range from conservative care for closed, nondisplaced extra-articular CF to surgical reduction with fixation for cases with compromised subtalar joint function. There is not consensus on the best surgical techniques, although there is growing support for less invasive procedures(14)

Management of patients with CF involves non-weight-bearing  (NWB) in the early healing phase, followed by progressive weight-bearing  (WB) and rehabilitation exercises to restore strength, ROM, and functional capacity –There is growing support for earlier physical therapy intervention with CF(15,16)
Chronic subtalar joint stiffness, foot pain, and abnormal gait may develop, especially in patients with loss of heel height, increased heel width, or severe articular surface displacement(14)

ICD-10 codes.S92.0: fracture of calcaneus (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for CF
presentation signs and symptoms: Patients usually present with orders for rehabilitation and restricted WB, often after the NWB phase of management (up to 12 weeks)
Use of ambulatory assistive device (e.g., crutches, rolling knee walker, wheelchair)
Heel contour may be distorted in severe cases
Resolving plantar ecchymosis and hematoma (Mondor sign)
Healing of surgical incision and/or soft tissue wounds
Reduced sensation of foot and ankle joint proprioception
Impaired strength and flexibility of affected foot and lower extremity. Weak or absent plantar flexion following avulsion CF
Potential neurovascular compromise Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: The talus usually acts like a wedge, causing compressive and widening forces at the angle of Gissane of the calcaneal body(i.e.,formed by the downward and upward slopes of the calcaneal superior surface –normally 120–145˚)(14)
Most common - high-energy  direct trauma on the hindfoot as in a (14)–motor vehicle collision–fall or jump from significant height–blunt blow
Repetitive overuse (e.g., running) without protective footwear (barefoot or wearing “minimalist” shoes) may promotecalcaneal stress fracture

Combat-related  CF is common in military personnel(3)–Rapid acceleration beneath the feet (i.e., “deck-slap” injury) due to high-velocity,low-amplitude  force directed superiorlyalong the axis of the axial skeleton, similar to jump landing; associated with very high rates of concomitant injuries andextensive soft tissue damage
pathogenesis: The calcaneus and talus have three articulating surfaces that make up the subtalar joint: the anterior, middle, and posteriorfacets. The posterior facet is the primary load-bearing  surface(14)

The Sanders method is the most commonly used system for classifying CF.(14) It utilizes coronal CT images showing theposterior facet and sustentaculum to determine the presence and extent of subtalar joint fragments/depression and classifiesCFs into four types (I–IV)  of displacement with increasing severity(10)–Type I: 1 nondisplaced or minimally displaced bony fragment–Type II: 2 bony fragments involving the posterior facet–Type III: 3 bony fragments, including an additional depressed middle fragment–Type IV: 4 comminuted bony fragments

Either open reduction with internal fixation (ORIF) or closed reduction with percutaneous fixation is indicated for unstableintra-articular  CF. However, there is not consensus on the best surgical technique to perform.The choice to operate needs tobe considered alongside the complications that can come with surgery(14)
The decision for operative management is based on the type of CF, soft tissue complications, and health of the patient(14)
Whether operative treatment is superior to conservative management for low-grade  intraarticular CF remainscontroversial(14)
Post-traumatic  arthritis is a common complication after CF and may require subtalar arthrodesis or ankle joint arthroplastyin the long term
Associated neurovascular injuries are uncommon with calcaneal fractures(10)
Peroneal tendon instability is relatively common with CF(17)

overall contraindications precautions: Pediatric cases require informed consent of a parent or legal guardian
Remain vigilant for adverse signs (e.g., unremitting pain at rest, paresthesias)
Suspect deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in cases with persistent calf swelling, warmth, redness, and tenderness
Obtain specific WB instructions from physician; inquire about any other mobility restrictions. NWB is often prescribed for up to 12 weeks
Continue to reinforce compliance with WB orders as symptoms improve
Obtain physician orders prior to initiating any new treatment
Aggravating or painful activities are contraindicated even after fracture healing is confirmed
Beware of calluses or bunions becoming ulcerated and infected during immobilization period
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan

contraindications precautions to examina: Confirm that distal pulses are present

Stop the examination and immediately report signs and symptoms suggestive of neurovascular compromise to physician (e.g., if sensation is impaired or the patient cannot demonstrate a motor response in the affected foot)
Observe for signs of fracture displacement and report to physician
Consult physician in cases with unexpected inflammation, infection, or poor healing of soft tissues

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document date and cause of injury. The onset is often sudden and traumatic (see Causes , above)

course of treatment.medical management: What modification of regular physical activities has physician recommended? Sanders type I and most extraarticular CF are usually treated conservatively with rest, ice, elevation, and early ROM. Splinting should be discontinued after 510  days and early ROM of the ankle and hindfoot should commence to minimize stiffness.(14) What are the prescribed WB restrictions? Was the foot immobilized in a cast or boot? If so, for how long?
surgical management: Surgical management: What operative procedure was used: ORIF or closed reduction with percutaneous fixation? Were there complications during or soon after surgery?
Goals of surgery include reduction of the posterior facet to as normal as possible and restoration of overall calcaneal morphology(12)
Postoperative complications include infection and skin necrosis, skin irritation by metal implants, redisplacement of
the reduced fragment, neurovascular injury, posttraumatic  arthritis, and malunion(4,11)
course of treatment.medications: Document what medications clinician has prescribed and whether they are being taken and are helpful. Postoperative pain management may include strong analgesics (e.g., opioids), NSAIDs, or acetaminophen
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
CT scans are usually obtained to identify the type of fracture and are also helpful to evaluate the outcomes of surgically treated CF
X-rays  are taken as indicated to rule out other foot or lower extremity fractures/conditions
Surgical patients typically undergo preoperative chest X-ray;  blood tests, including complete cell count (CBC),
hemoglobin/hematocrit, and type and crossmatch;  kidney and liver function tests; ECG; and postoperative CT scan of ankle
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0 to 10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Does the patient sleep supine with the affected ankle elevated?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, shortness of breath) -General anesthesia increases the patient’s risk for myocardial infarction, stroke, pneumonia, and blood clots -Symptoms of blood clots/DVT in the leg include redness, warmth, pain, tenderness, and swelling of the leg; refer to physician urgently if these symptoms are present -Chest pain and shortness of breath can indicate that a clot has traveled to the lungs
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is the patient using portable supplemental oxygen? If so, what is the patient’s respiratory status for WB? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__/No__ -If Yes, describe

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document prior lower extremity trauma or fracture. Ask about other lower extremity surgeries
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the patient currently working or in school? Does patient have a sedentary or physically active job? Does the job require the patient to be on their feet? Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, who patient lives with, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? -To ensure safety, environmental modifications such as installation of grab bars, use of assistive devices such as a shower chair, and removing loose carpets may be necessary -The patient may require the creation of a temporary living space on a first floor or somewhere close to a bathroom during the NWB phase

relevant tests and measures.general: While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to ›Relevant tests and measures:  While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document height and weight. Determine BMI and whether patient appears overweight or obese. Patients with extremely elevated BMI (> 45) have increased risk of in-hospital  and outpatient complications after surgery
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Most patients present NWB and using an ambulatory assistive device
relevant tests and measures.balance: After FWB status is achieved, assess static and dynamic balance of the involved leg, using assistive device as needed. Administer Functional Reach Test or Berg Balance Scale, as appropriate
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Confirm that pedal pulses are intact, especially in cases with hematoma/hemarthrosisAssess for swelling. Measure figure-8 circumference of the affected ankle and compare to uninvolved leg As appropriate for stage of healing, assess ability in sit-to-stand, turning, stooping, kneeling, squatting, and sitting down. Functional mobility can be assessed with marching-on-the-spot,  use of stairs, and the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test. Also assess walking agility, including tandem gait and turns. Administer FIM as indicated
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess ability to maintain WB status in standing. Patient may wear walker/walking boot after NWB phase. When FWB, assess gait asymmetry or abnormality in unassisted walking. Observe for stiff ankle pattern on involved side as well as any other gait abnormalities or asymmetries. Gait deficits may include flat-walking  pattern, decreased stride length, decreased speed/cadence, decreased endurance, decreased stance time, poor weight shift, decreased normal heel toe progression, hip hiking, and circumduction Joint integrity and mobility –Assess mobility of the ankle when fracture has healed. Also assess the ankle movers for tightness that might have developed during immobilization -Chronic subtalar joint stiffness is common,as isloss of heel height, increased heel width, or severe articular surface displacement(14) –Delay testing for ligamentous mobility until the patient is FWB
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength of lower extremity muscles using manual muscle testing (MMT), when appropriate, and compare to uninvolved leg. Expect weakness in ankle plantar flexion, dorsiflexion, inversion, and eversion
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess skin condition and stage of healing of bruises/cuts/incisions/warmth and redness (post trauma or surgery)
Assess pain and tenderness using V AS
Assess tone of lower extremity muscles
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess alignment of affected foot. When FWB, assess foot posture and alignment of lower extremity in standing and during walking. Check for leg-length  discrepancy
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess active-assisted/active  and passive ROM of the lower extremity, when appropriate. Expect insufficient active ROM of ankle compared to uninvolved side
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess patellar tendon and Achilles tendon reflexesReview disabilities to determine whether patient is independent at home/work
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Assess sensation in lower extremity (including foot and toes)and compare to unaffected side, with special attention to the L5, S1 dermatomes –Assess proprioception in lower extremity with special attention to ankle joint
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special testsa scale for rating standing foot posture using set criteriaa self-report  instrument for assessing foot-specific  pain and disability –Lower Extremity Function Scale (LEFS) –American Orthopedic Foot and Ankle Society Hindfoot Scale (AOFAS) –Medical Outcomes Study Short Form (SF-36)

contraindications precautions: Avoid applying cold over superficial nerves, areas of diminished sensation or poor circulation, or slow-healing wounds
Use caution with patients who are hypertensive, as cold can cause a transient increase in blood pressure; discontinue treatment if there is an elevation in blood pressure
Use caution with patients who are hypersensitive to cold
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Use of cryotherapy with patients who have an aversion to cold may be counterproductive if being used to promote muscle relaxation and decrease pain
electrotherapy contraindications precaut: Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
In an area with infection or bleeding
If a tumor is present in the area
In the area of DVT or thrombophlebitis
Over epiphyseal plates of growing bones
Use caution in patients with sensory deficits and in patients who are unable to communicate sensory deficits
Use caution if patient has circulatory impairments
Use caution over plastic or metal implants
Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
Functional deficits in posture, balance, gait, and walking ability
other: Observe general contraindications and precautions listed above

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
Ensure compliance with parameters of rehabilitation protocol prescribed by physician
Modify therapeutic exercises to allow for patient’s functional limitations (e.g., frailty, easy fatigability, poor balance/ coordination, increased fall risk)
Educate and prepare patient for an independent (home, gym, or pool-based)  exercise program after discharge, as indicated

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Superficial heat  is contraindicated with the following:(1)

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions include: (in rare cases, and only when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the conditions listed below if the potential benefit outweighs the perceived risk)(1)
Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications include; do not use(1)
Diagnosis/need for treatment . The following issues may need to be addressed when working with a patient with CF:

assessment plan of care.rule out: In trauma cases, confirm that there are no other injuries to the lower extremities and spine. Approximately 10% of patients with CF will have associated thoracolumbar vertebral and contralateral calcaneal injuries(14) Rule out DVT, compartment syndrome, and other concomitant adverse events Patients with CF resulting from a motor vehicle collision are more likely to have associated injuries(13)
prognosis: Prognosis is poorest in cases in whichopen surgery is performed but anatomic reconstruction is not accomplished(14)
Long-term  functional outcomes vary widely in patients with CF but appear to decline from good for type I versus poor for type IV in the Sanders classification(14)

Authors of a retrospective case-control  study (N = 44 patients treated for CF) in Germany found that the Boehler angle (i.e., theangle between two lines tangent to the calcaneus on lateral radiograph) was a valid predictor of functional outcomes after a mean follow-up  of 9.5 years(5) –Normal Boehler angle is between 20 and 40 °.Angles less than 20 ° are found soon after CF –Outcomes of patients with a marked reduction in Boehler angle on admission were significantly worse than those of patients with a preserved or only slightly reduced Boehler angle –In contrast, the Gissane angle, Sanders classification, Larsen stage of subtalar arthrosis, and type of treatment (operative or conservative) were not valuable predictors of long-term  functional outcomes

Authors of a cohort study (N = 30 patients with Sanderstype II and III CF) in London found that percutaneous arthroscopic calcaneal osteosynthesis resulted in the following outcomes at 2-year follow-up:(7) –Boehler angle increased from 11.10° at admission to 23.41° –High self-reported  functional outcomes and return to preinjury employment levels

Authors of a 2015 systematic review on displaced intra-articular calcaneal fracture (DIACF) found that DIACF was a life-changing event in most cases.(8) Lifestyle alterations include change in type of work, reduced participation in recreational activities, more supportive footwear, and use of ambulatory assistive devices(13)

Based on a 2013 Cochrane review, high-quality  evidence relating to current practice for CF is lacking to determine whether surgical or conservative treatment provides better outcomes for adults with Sanders grade I minimallydisplaced intra-articular  CF(2)

Based on an RCT in China, preoperative single dose of tranexamic acid (TXA) can effectively reduce wound complications and postoperative blood loss in patients with CF(6) –90 patients were randomized to either the TXA group or the control group –Wound complications and postoperative blood loss were reduced in the TXA group as compared to the control group. There were no significant side effects of the single dose of TXA
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Pain management specialist, vocational rehabilitation counselor, occupational therapist (OT), orthotist for orthotics
other considerations: Authors of a 2018 systematic review and meta-analysis  found that the overall prevalence of peroneal tendon instability after calcaneal fracture was 29.3%(17) –The prevalence of peroneal tendon instability increased as severity increased (measured by Sanders classification) -Sanders I – 5.4% -Sanders II – 19% -Sanders III – 39.4% -Sanders IV – 49.5% –The presence of a fleck sign (i.e., a cortical avulsion fracture of the distal fibula) with CF was found to be a strong indicator of peroneal instability, with 54.7% of patients with a fleck sign having peroneal instability
treatment summary: Management usually consists of splinting/casting and NWB for up to 12 weeks followed by progressive WB and rehabilitative exercises. Gentle ROM may begin as early as 1 to 2 weeks after injury when immobilization is converted to a fracture boot. Whether early ROM improves outcome remains unclear

Six to nine weeks of NWB is usually recommended for postoperative displaced intra-articular  calcaneal fractures(15) –However, authors of a 2018 systematic review and pooled analysis concluded that there were no negative outcomes associated with starting partial weight-bearing  6 weeks postoperatively(15)
No rehabilitation guidelines are available for CF. Treatment will vary on an individual basis depending on fracture severity and the physician’s orders

Although physical therapy is not usually started until 6 weeks after surgery, a 2018 RCT conducted in the United States showed that ROM and manual therapy initiated at 2 weeks postoperatively may improve long-term  outcomes and prevent complications(16) –Participants were 50 consecutive patients undergoing operative fixation of a hindfoot fracture (talus or calcaneus) –Outcome measures collected at 3 and 6 months: AOFAS, the LEFS, active ROM, swelling, and pain –Significant differences were found on the AOFAS and the LEFS. No differences were found in ROM, swelling, and pain at 6 months

The general rehabilitation plan will likely include the following components and individualized progression –Cryotherapy and analgesics (often acetaminophen) for pain, inflammation, and swelling –Active and active-assisted  stretching exercises and manual therapy to improve ROM and flexibility –Progressive resistance exercise (PRE) to increase strength and to improve balance and functional mobility –Functional training to address deficits in posture, gait, and balance –Balance training for falls prevention in ambulatory patients –Patient education for independent care and exercise and functional training . maintenance or prevention: Continue therapeutic exercise plan to maintain the highest achievable foot ROM, strength, and functional mobility
Use proper footwear for everyday physical activity and sport
